Fig. 1 TEM micrographs and the corresponding histograms for the Ru/C catalysts: (a) Ru/C(600); (b) Ru/C(700); (c) Ru/C(800); (d) Ru/C(900); (e) Ru/C(1000). Notice that (a) corresponds to a HR-TEM micrograph of sample Ru/C(600), while (b)–(e) are TEM images of sample Ru/C(700)–(1000), respectively. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Ru K-edge FT-EXAFS spectra for the Ru foil, RuO2, Ru/C(800) and Ru/C(imp) catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Catalytic activity of the Ru-based catalysts in the AB hydrolysis reaction at 30°C. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 TOF number (mol H2/mol Ru min) calculated at t=5.5min for the Ru/C samples prepared by Ru complex decomposition. The data were average TOF numbers calculated after performing three different catalytic tests. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Catalytic performance dependence of catalyst Ru/C(800) with the reaction temperature. Table 4 Run TOF (mol H2/mol Ru min) Conversion (%) 1st 718 100 2nd 575 100 3rd 517 100 4th 460 100 5th 417 97 Highly efficient Ru/carbon catalysts prepared by pyrolysis of supported Ru complex towards the hydrogen production from ammonia borane Miriam Navlani-García a Kohsuke Mori a b c ⁎ Ai Nozaki a Yasutaka Kuwahara a b Hiromi Yamashita a b ⁎ a Division of Materials and Manufacturing Science, Graduate School of Engineering, Osaka University, 2-1 Yamada-oka, Suita, Japan Division of Materials and Manufacturing Science Graduate School of Engineering Osaka University 2-1 Yamada-oka Suita Japan b Unit of Elements Strategy Initiative for Catalysts & Batteries, Kyoto University, Katsura, Kyoto 615-8520, Japan Unit of Elements Strategy Initiative for Catalysts & Batteries Kyoto University Katsura Kyoto 615-8520 Japan c PRESTO, JST, Honcho, Kawaguchi, Saitama 332-0012, Japan PRESTO JST Honcho Kawaguchi Saitama 332-0012 Japan ⁎ Corresponding authors at: Division of Materials and Manufacturing Science, Graduate School of Engineering, Osaka University, 2-1 Yamada-oka, Suita, Japan. Division of Materials and Manufacturing Science Graduate School of Engineering Osaka University 2-1 Yamada-oka Suita Japan Graphical abstract Highly efficient carbon-supported Ru catalysts towards the H2 production from the ammonia borane (AB: NH3BH3) hydrolysis reaction have been developed by using tri(2,2′-bipyridyl) ruthenium (II) chloride hexahydrate as metal precursor. Different temperatures were used to decompose the metal precursor, which afford the preparation of various nanoparticles sizes, ranging from 3.8 to 13.5nm. The catalytic results revealed that both geometric and electronic features of the metal nanoparticles are crucial to attain optimum catalytic activity towards the H2 production from the hydrolysis of AB. The optimum catalyst under the experimental condition used was that prepared at 800°C, which efficiently boosts the hydrolysis of AB, achieving an average TOF number of 670mol H2/mol metal min, which is among the highest values ever reported for a monometallic Ru catalyst in this reaction up to date. Keywords Hydrogen production Ammonia borane Ru nanoparticles Metal complex Nanoparticle size 1 Introduction Hydrogen (H2) is currently a worldwide accepted environmentally clean energy carrier by combining with the proton exchange membranes (PEM) technology, which offers a solution for the energy problem as well as for the environmental pollution originated from the fossil fuels [1–3]. However, the hydrogen-based economy still needs to face with important problems related to controlled H2 storage and release [2,4]. In this sense, H2 can be stored using both physical and chemical methods and the search for an optimum material for the H2 storage is still the target of many researches [5–7]. Among the huge variety of materials used for the H2 storage, ammonia borane (NH3-BH3, AB) is considered as the most promising chemical H2 storage material, which is due to its remarkable theoretical gravimetric H2 content (19.6wt.%, 6.5 and 13.1wt.% for the first and second equivalent of H2, respectively), low molecular weight (30.87g/mol), stability in solid state, solution under ambient conditions and nontoxicity [8–14]. Then, as a consequence of these promising properties, important efforts have been directed towards the fine tuning of the H2 release from AB, as well as the regeneration from the dehydrogenated “spent fuel” materials [15,16]. The H2 release can take place by following different pathways, both pyrolysis [17] or hydrolysis, being the last one the most convenient route, as H2 can be released at room temperature in presence of a suitable catalyst producing as much as 3mol of H2 per mol of AB by following Eq. (1) [8,18]. (1) NH3−BH3 +2H2O→NH4BO2 +3H2 Various approaches, including both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts, have been already reported, but those catalytic systems containing noble metals are considered as the most favourable for this application [19,20]. Among them, Ru-based catalysts have been claimed as one of the most effective catalysts toward AB hydrolysis and great efforts have been devoted to the optimisation of these catalytic systems by tuning either the support used or the metal loading methodology [21–24]. Concerning the studied supports, a wide variety of materials, such as graphic carbon nitride [25], carbon black [26,27], carbon nanotubes [28], Al2O3 [21,29], hydroxyapatite [30,31], Metal Organic Frameworks [32], TiO2 [33] and so forth, have been already reported for this application. In addition, various metal salts and experimental approaches have been considered in order to develop efficient catalysts towards the AB hydrolysis. For instance, the in-situ generation of Ru(0) nanoparticles reduced by AB was studied by Akbayrak et al. [33], while a more complex system such as Ru@SiO2 nanospheres was prepared by Yao et al. [34] via a one-pot synthetic route by following a reversed-micelle technique, and the use of polymer-capped Ru-based metal nanoparticles was reported by Rakap [35]. Furthermore, bimetallic nanoparticles, both in core-shell or alloy configuration have been also investigated in the AB decomposition. In this regard, several compositions such as RuCo [36–38], RuNi [37], RuPt [35] and RuFe [37] have been proved to exhibit promising catalytic activity for H2 generation from the hydrolysis of AB. However, despite the huge variety of approaches considered, the search for an optimum catalyst to boost the AB hydrolysis is still the goal of many researches, as is demonstrated by the increasing number of publications dealing with this issue during the last years. Herein, we report a synthetic method of carbon-supported Ru nanoparticles (Ru/C) based on the impregnation of the Ru(bpy)3 2+ precursor on carbon support and the subsequent precursor decomposition by heat treatment at temperatures ranging from 600 to 1000°C. This parameter is proven to have an important impact on the final features of the catalysts, which ultimately reflected in the catalytic performance of Ru/C towards the hydrogen production from AB hydrolysis. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation In order to prepare the Ru/C catalysts 0.037g of tri(2,2′-bipyridyl) ruthenium (II) chloride hexahydrate was dissolved in 150mL of MeOH to obtain a target 0.5wt.% of Ru content. Then 1g of the support (commercial SHIRASAGI M (Osaka Gas Chemicals Co. Ltd. Carbon support) was added to the solution and the mixture was stirred for 2h at room temperature. Afterwards, it was vacuum dried at 40°C to remove the solvent completely (a filtration step was not used in order to avoid the possible metal lost). The obtained powder was then placed in a glass tube and heat treated at 600, 700, 800, 900 and 1000°C, in each instance for 2h under N2 atmosphere and using a heating rate of 5°C/min. In order to favour the reduction of the metal, the catalysts were reduced afterwards by using NaBH4 (Ru/NaBH4 molar ratio of 1/10) and stirring for 3h at room temperature. Then, the samples were washed with water until neutral and dried at 100°C overnight. The as-prepared catalysts were denoted as Ru/C(600), Ru/C(700), Ru/C(800), Ru/C(900) and Ru/C(1000), respectively. To elucidate the importance of the metal precursor and carbon support in the synthetic procedure used, two additional catalysts with the same metal loading (0.5wt.%) were prepared as reference samples. The first one was a Ru/C-based catalyst prepared using Ru(NO)(NO3)3 as Ru precursor. The carbon support was impregnated for 2h at room temperature with the adequate amount of the metal precursor aqueous solution and subsequently dried at 77°C under vacuum for 30min to remove the solvent. Then, the sample was placed in a glass tube and heat treated at 800°C (5°C/min) for 2h under N2 atmosphere. After that, the sample was reduced with NaBH4 by using the aforementioned procedure. This sample was denoted as Ru/C(imp). The second additional catalyst was a Ru/SiO2-based catalyst prepared from Ru(bpy)3 2+ and commercial fumed silica by conducting the same experimental steps as for the Ru/C(800) counterpart. 2.2 Catalysts characterisation Thermogravimetric analysis was performed by using a Rigaku Thermoplus EVO2. Porous texture characterisation of the carbon support and Ru/C catalysts was carried out by means of adsorption of N2 at −196°C by using a BELSORP-max system (BEL Japan, Inc.). Prior to the isothermal analysis, samples were degassed under vacuum at 250°C for 4h in order to remove any adsorbed impurities. Apparent surface area was calculated from N2 adsorption isotherms using the BET equation (SBET) at 10−3 <P/Po<10−2. Total micropore volume (VDR(N2)) was calculated applying the Dubinin–Radushkevich (DR) equation to the N2 adsorption data. Ru loading was determined by using ICP-OES (inductively coupled plasma-optical emission Spectroscopy). Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) micrographs were recorded using a Hitachi H-800 electron microscope equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) detector, operated at 200kV. High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HR-TEM) was used for the proper determination of the average nanoparticle size of those samples which displayed smaller nanoparticles. To prepare the samples for the TEM analysis, a small amount of the catalyst was suspended in ethanol and sonicated in an ultrasonic bath for few seconds. After that, a drop of this suspension was deposited onto a copper grid and dried at room temperature. Ru K-edge XAFS spectra were recorded using a fluorescence-yield collection technique at the beam line 01B1 station with an attached Si (111) monochromator at SPring-8, JASRI, Harima, Japan (prop. No. 2015A1149). The EXAFS data were normalized by fitting the background absorption coefficient, around the energy region higher than the edge of about 35–50eV, with the smoothed absorption of an isolated atom. The EXAFS data were examined using the Rigaku EXAFS analysis program. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were recorded using an ESCA 3400 Electron Spectrometer and the quantitative analyses were done from the integrated intensities of the spectra. Although Ru is normally analysed by following the signals from the 3d photoelectrons, herein the 3p spectra are used instead to avoid interferences from the C 1s spectrum of the carbon support. 2.3 Catalytic tests In order to assess the catalytic performance in the hydrolysis of AB, 0.02g of Ru-based catalysts and 10mL of distilled water were placed into a Schlenk-type reaction vessel (30mL) connected with a gas burette. The system was purged 3 times with nitrogen gas. After this, the reaction was initiated by introducing 1mL of aqueous solution of AB (containing 1.5mmol of AB) and the mixture was gently stirred while the evolution of the H2 production was monitored by using the gas burette system. In the standard experiments, the reaction temperature was maintained at 30°C by using an oil bath. The catalytic tests were performed three times to evaluate the reproducibility of the reaction. Additional experiments at different reaction temperatures were also carried out with Ru/C(800) to calculate the activation energy. The reusability of Ru/C(800) was evaluated by conducting five consecutives runs. For this purpose, the spent catalyst was kept in the reactor while a new aqueous solution of AB (1mL, containing 1.5mmol of AB) was added and the hydrogen output was monitored under the same experimental condition as for the first reaction cycle. 3 Results & discussion The thermogravimetric (TG) analysis profiles obtained with the bare Ru(bpy)3 2+ complex used as Ru precursor showed the sharp decomposition peak at around 400°C, as shown in Fig. S1(a). On the other hand, the decomposition of the carbon-supported Ru(bpy)3 2+ complex before the calcination step gradually occurs and delayed its decomposition temperature to higher degree, which is due to the stronger interaction between carbon support and metal complex (Fig. S1(b)). The results obtained from the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms indicated the Type I isotherms without blockage of the porosity even after the Ru loading (See Fig. S2 and Table S1). Fig. 1 shows the TEM images and the pertinent histograms with the Ru nanoparticle size distribution for all Ru/C catalysts and the data obtained from the counting of ∼200 nanoparticles is collected in Table 1 . The clear observation of Ru nanoparticles suggests that the Ru complex decomposed to form Ru nanoparticles even when the sample is prepared at the lowest temperatures. In all samples, Ru nanoparticles have spherical shape in a homogeneous distribution on the carbon surface. However, important differences in the average nanoparticle size and size distribution are observed; the average Ru particle size increased with increasing the temperature used to prepare the samples, which led to a notable broadening of the nanoparticle size distribution. As expected, this effect is especially important in sample Ru/C(1000), where nanoparticles as large as 50nm can be observed in the TEM image. This tendency is in good agreement with results addressed elsewhere [39,40]. In contrast, samples Ru/C(imp) and Ru/SiO2, treated at 800°C (See Fig. S3), showed smaller NP size and narrower size distribution than that prepared from Ru(bpy)3 2+ (3.3, 2.0 and 7.0nm for Ru/C(imp), Ru/SiO2 and Ru/C(800), respectively). The results of the ICP characterisation listed in Table 1 revealed that the final Ru loading (wt.%) is very close to the targeted 0.5wt.% for all the as-prepared catalysts. X-Ray absorption measurements were performed in order to elucidate the effect of the metal precursors on the Ru state in the Ru/C(800) and Ru/C(imp) samples. Fig. 2 shows the Fourier Transforms (FT) k 3-weighted Ru K-edge extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) of these samples. As it can be seen, both catalysts as well as RuO2 showed a first peak at around 1.5Å due to the RuO bond [41]. In addition, a second peak was also observed at around 2.4Å, which can be assigned to the contiguous RuRu bond in the metallic form [42–44]. It should be highlighted that the relative intensity of these two peaks is different in both catalysts, in which the contribution of RuRu bonds in the sample Ru/C(800) prepared by using Ru(bpy)3 2+ precursor is higher than that in the Ru/C(imp) using Ru(NO)(NO3)3. This result suggests that the size of Ru nanoparticles in the sample Ru/C(800) is larger than that in the Ru/C(imp), which is in good agreement with the TEM results. It can be said that kinetics of the reduction of Ru precursor under calcination conditions plays a crucial role in determining the particle size. Generally, the rapid reduction generates more nuclei of Ru metals in a shorter period and efficiently suppresses the growth of metal nanoparticles, while slow reduction produces less nuclei, which lead to the growth of metal nanoparticles. Thus, the difference in the nanoparticles size can be ascribed to the different reduction kinetics when different metal precursors are used, which in turn might be related to different metal precursor-support interactions. Concerning the electronic properties of the resulting nanoparticles, the interaction between Ru precursor and the carbon support might have an important influence in the oxidation state of the Ru species. Dam and Bekkum proposed two types of ligand sites, oxygen-containing functional groups and π-complex structures (π-sites), for the preparation of carbon-supported Pt catalysts from Pt precursor [45]. According to this study, the oxidised Pt species tend to be formed on the oxygen-containing functional groups, while the metallic Pt nanoparticles are preferentially formed on the π-sites. In our case, a larger proportion of metallic Ru nanoparticles can be observed in Ru/C(800) prepared using Ru(bpy)3 2+ than in Ru/C(imp) by using Ru(NO)(NO3)3, as evidenced by the relative intensity of the peaks corresponding to RuO and RuRu in the EXAFS spectra (See Fig. 2). This fact might indicate that the nanoparticles tend to be preferentially formed in the π-sites when Ru(bpy)3 2+ was used as metal precursor, while Ru(NO)(NO3)3 is more prone to decompose near the oxygen-containing functional groups. To further analyse the electronic state of the Ru nanoparticles, XPS characterisation was carried out by recording the spectra in the 3p region. The results revealed the presence of two bands corresponding to the 3p3/2 and 3p1/2 transitions, having a binding energy of about 462.5 and 485.5eV, respectively. The deconvolution of both bands as a doublet, and the integration of the resulting peaks, attributed to the presence of Ru in the metallic form and oxidised state [46,47], gave information about the relative proportion of reduced and oxidised Ru species in the catalysts (See Table 2 ). These results pointed out the pivotal importance of both metal complex decomposition temperature and the interaction between the metal precursor and graphene structure of carbon support in controlling the electronic features of the resulting Ru nanoparticles. The comparison of samples Ru/C(800) and Ru/C(imp) suggested the larger relative proportion of Ru(0) in Ru/C(800) compared to Ru/C(imp), which empathised the importance of the interaction with the π-sites when Ru(bpy)3 2+ is used as metal precursor. 3.1 Catalytic activity in the AB hydrolysis The AB conversion profiles obtained with the Ru-catalysts are plotted in Fig. 3 . As it can be seen, the temperature used to prepare the catalysts exhibits a remarkable effect on the catalytic activity of the Ru/C samples. The conversion profiles indicated that no induction period was observed for all catalysts. Complete conversion of AB was achieved by using Ru/C(800), Ru/C(900) and Ru/C(1000), while AB hydrolysis did not take place completely in the cases of Ru/C(600), Ru/C(700), Ru/C(imp) and Ru/SiO2. These results indicated that relatively larger size of Ru nanoparticles is indispensable for attaining complete reaction. As shown in Fig. 4 , a volcano type relationship was found between TOF values (calculated at t=5.5min) based on Ru and the temperature used to prepare the Ru/C catalysts. The best-performing sample achieved an average TOF of 670mol H2 mol Rumin−1, which, to the best of our knowledge, is among the highest values ever reported for a monometallic Ru catalyst up to date (See Table 3 ). The pivotal importance of the metal precursor-support interaction is pointed out by the comparison of the catalytic activity shown by Ru/C(600)–(1000) and the two additional reference samples, prepared with either different support or different metal precursor. As it can be seen in Fig. 3, in the case of using the sample Ru/SiO2, the reaction was sluggish as compared to the Ru/C catalysts and the maximum conversion (∼97%) is significantly delayed, while, even though the initial reaction rate using the catalyst prepared by using Ru(NO)(NO3)3 (Ru/C(imp)) is similar to those displayed by Ru/C(600)-(1000) catalysts, a total AB decomposition was not achieved in that case. The reaction temperature has a noticeable effect on the catalytic performance of Ru/C(800) catalyst and the H2 generation rate was enhanced with increasing the reaction temperature (See Fig. 5 ). These experiments conducted at different temperatures were used to calculate the activation energy (E a) for the AB hydrolysis catalysed by Ru/C(800) according to the Arrhenius Equations (Eq. (2)), where A is the frequency factor, R is the ideal gas constant and T is the reaction temperature (See Fig. S4). The activation energy was calculated to be 14.3kJ/mol, which is one of the lowest values among reported for Ru-based catalysts so far, highlighting the superior catalytic performance of the present Ru/C catalytic system (See Table 3). (2) ln k = ln A − E a R T Furthermore, the reusability of Ru/C(800) was investigated by performing five consecutive runs at 30°C (Fig. 6 ). The results of the TOF after 5.5min and maximum conversion are summarised in Table 4 . The reaction proceeded smoothly and almost complete conversion could be attained even in the fifth run, but the TOF value decreased gradually, which was about 60% of the initial TOF in the fifth run. The loss of activity could be tentatively attributed to the following reasons: nanoparticle sintering under the experimental condition used, changes in the electronic state of the Ru nanoparticles and/or effect of the accumulated metaborate in the medium [51]. In order to elucidate the main responsible for the gradual catalytic activity decay, some additional experiments were conducted. Firstly, the effect of the nanoparticle size increase after the catalytic run on the catalytic activity decay was ruled out by recording TEM micrographs after the first run (See Fig. S5). In this case the sample showed an average Ru nanoparticle size of 7.1±3.1nm, which is very similar to that showed by the fresh counterpart (7.0±3.4nm). In addition post-reaction XPS analysis of sample Ru/C(800) after five catalytic runs was also performed and the results indicated that the relative proportion of metallic and oxidised species was slightly different from that found in the fresh sample (76.7 and 67.1 atomic% of Ru(0) for the fresh and used catalyst, respectively). Interestingly, XPS analysis revealed the presence of B-containing species on the catalyst surface, which might be also responsible of the loss of catalytic activity. Therefore, according to these experimental evidences, the catalytic activity decay observed along the consecutive runs can be attributed to these adverse factors but the negative effect of the accumulated metaborate in the medium should not be ruled out. The relatively poor stability displayed by the catalyst indicates that further efforts should be directed towards the improvement of the stability and recyclability of the present catalytic system for practical application. The catalytic performance displayed by the studied samples might be related to geometric and electronic aspect of the Ru-based catalysts. On the one hand, the volcano type relationship between the catalytic activity and the temperature used to prepare the catalysts might be attributed to the effect of this experimental parameter in controlling the final nanoparticle size. Sample Ru/C(800) with a moderate average nanoparticle size among investigated, displayed better performance towards the hydrolysis of AB than those catalysts with smaller or larger nanoparticles. Similar phenomena has been claimed in the case of the Pt catalyst supported on CNTs for the hydrolysis of AB [57], where the catalyst with nanoparticle size of 1.8nm showed the optimum catalytic activity. Furthermore, it was also found in that work that the smaller Pt particles appear to have lower durability, which was attributed to the more significant adsorption of B-containing species on the Pt surface. It is well-known that a plausible mechanism for the hydrolysis of AB is initiated by the formation of an activated complex species between NH3BH3 and the metal particle surface. This reaction intermediate undergoes the attack by a H2O molecule, which readily leads to concerted dissociation of the BN bonding and hydrolysis of the resulting BH3 intermediate to produce the boric acid product along with the H2 release [58,59]. Therefore, it seems logical to think that the ability to form Ru-NH3BH3 activated complex, which is strongly related to the Ru nanoparticles size, may exert an important influence on the final catalytic performance. As mentioned before, there is an optimum Ru nanoparticle size for boosting the AB hydrolysis, which in our case appeared for sample Ru/C(800) with Ru particles of 7nm. It is generally accepted that the smaller metal particles lead to better catalytic performance because they have a larger proportion of unsaturated surface atoms. This would be in good agreement with the better performance of sample Ru/C(800) compared to those attained by Ru/C(900) and Ru/C(1000) whose average Ru particles sizes were 11.1 and 13.5nm, respectively. However, it seems harder to explain the inferior catalytic activity of Ru/C(600) and Ru/C(700) (3.8 and 6.2nm, respectively). In this point, it could be assumed that the ability to form the Ru-NH3BH3 activated complex formed in the first stage of the reaction might be higher in the smaller particle size, leading therefore to space exclusion and repulsive adsorbate–adsorbate interaction. Such obstruction may inhibit the subsequent attack by H2O molecules to reach the NH3BH3-based metallic complex. Bearing these results in mind, it could be extracted that reaching a balance between the higher reactivity and the space exclusion originated from smaller particles is mandatory to find an optimum catalyst towards the H2 production from the AB hydrolytic dehydrogenation. Another explanation for the optimum catalytic performance attained by the Ru/C(800) might be associated with the specific catalytic site on the appropriate Ru particle size. It has been reported that the atomic arrangement is strongly related to its particle size. In this line, metals such as platinum, palladium, nickel or ruthenium have been addressed to form so-called B5-type sites. The B5-type sites are defined as consisting of five metal atoms in a certain three dimensional arrangement with three Ru atoms in one layer (i.e., a kind of terrace) and two further Ru in the layer directly above this at a monoatomic step on a Ru (0001) terrace [60,61]. The majority of such active sites were recognised to be favourably present at edges related to low-coordinated surface atoms, e.g., edge atoms on (110) and (113) planes and formed only on medium-sized nanoparticles with a mean diameters of 1.5–7.0nm [62]. The specific contribution of such unique catalytic sites in the AB dehydrogenation cannot be ruled out. Actually, it is accepted that the B5-type sites are responsible for strong physical adsorption of nitrogen, thus efficiently boosting structure-sensitive catalytic reaction exemplified by the NH3 catalytic decomposition [60,63]. Furthermore, the electronic features of the resulting Ru nanoparticles seem to play a crucial role in determining the final catalytic activity. In this study, an optimal proportion of metallic/oxidised Ru species, which was achieved in sample Ru/C(800), is mandatory to attain high catalytic activity. These results indicate that not only the presence of reduced Ru nanoparticles, but also a moderate proportion of oxidised species is indispensable to efficiently catalyse the AB hydrolysis. The importance of the oxidised species in the present application has already been claimed elsewhere [8,63,64]. According to previous studies, the metal-catalysed hydrolysis of AB takes place by the following steps [65]: (1) NH3-BH3 molecule and metal nanoparticles surface form an activated complex where the interaction of the H2O molecules dissociates the BN bound; (2) NH3 ions release as ammonia hydroxide and BH3 − chemisorbed on the metal atoms transfers a H− to a free adjacent metal atom; (3) This H− leaves the metal site and reacts with H2O to produce H2 and OH−; (4) OH− reacts with boron in BH2 −, generating BH2(OH)−; 5) H− is transferred from BH2(OH)− to a free adjacent metal atom and BH(OH)− is formed. Steps 4 and 5 are repeated once more until B(OH)3 − and H2 is released. According to this mechanism, it has also been claimed that oxidised species are crucial for this reaction, as they have been reported to act as Lewis acid sites for OH− absorption due to the strong affinity of these sites toward oxygen of the OH− group [66] and the resulting polarization of the OH− groups would make them more prone to react with the boron species attached to the reduced metal sites. In our case, the importance of the oxidised species can be clearly observed by comparing the poorer behaviour displayed by Ru/SiO2 sample, where Ru is mainly in the metallic state, with those showed by Ru/C samples, where the contribution of Ru oxidised species is much more important. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, highly efficient Ru/C catalysts towards the ammonia borane decomposition reaction have been successfully prepared by using Ru(bpy)3 2+ as metal precursor. The effect of the decomposition complex temperature in the final catalytic performance was assessed by synthesising different samples with temperatures ranging from 600 to 1000°C. Additional catalysts have also been evaluated to elucidate the role of the Ru-catalysts features. The optimum catalyst under the experimental condition used was shown to be the sample Ru/C(800) with average NP size of 7.0nm, which efficiently boosts the hydrolysis of ammonia borane, achieving 100% of conversion and with an average TOF number of 670mol H2/mol metal min, which, as far as we are aware, is among the highest values ever reported for a monometallic Ru catalyst in the hydrolysis of ammonia borane up to date. The outstanding catalytic performance displayed by the sample Ru/C(800) as compared to those prepared by using different heat treatment temperatures, as well as different metal precursor and catalyst support, points out the importance of both electronic and geometric parameters in controlling the final properties of the studied Ru/C catalysts towards the efficient production of H2 from the hydrolytic dehydrogenation of ammonia borane. We expect that this synthetic strategy will be extendable in the deposition of other catalyst metals. The further study is now under investigation in our laboratory. coredata.dc:description: Highly efficient carbon-supported Ru catalysts towards the H2 production from the ammonia borane (AB: NH3BH3) hydrolysis reaction have been developed by using tri(2,2′-bipyridyl) ruthenium (II) chloride hexahydrate as metal precursor. Different temperatures were used to decompose the metal precursor, which afford the preparation of various nanoparticles sizes, ranging from 3.8 to 13.5nm. The catalytic results revealed that both geometric and electronic features of the metal nanoparticles are crucial to attain optimum catalytic activity towards the H2 production from the hydrolysis of AB. The optimum catalyst under the experimental condition used was that prepared at 800°C, which efficiently boosts the hydrolysis of AB, achieving an average TOF number of 670mol H2/mol metal min, which is among the highest values ever reported for a monometallic Ru catalyst in this reaction up to date.
coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient Ru/carbon catalysts prepared by pyrolysis of supported Ru complex towards the hydrogen production from ammonia borane
